"[1595-the old lady] [She]1595-the old lady bent down , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia , to [her]67-sylvia confusion and surprise , felt [her]67-sylvia cheeks lightly kissed by the withered lips of [[Paul de Virieu]94-count paul 's godmother]1597-paul de virieu 's godmother . " [Madame Bailey]67-sylvia 's rouge is natural ; it does not come off ! "[1595-the old lady] [the old lady]1595-the old lady exclaimed , and a smile crept over [her]1595-the old lady parchment - coloured face . " Not but what a great deal of nonsense is talked about the usage of rouge , [[my]1595-the old lady dear children]3428-my dear children ! There is no harm in supplementing the niggardly gifts of nature . [You]67-sylvia , for instance , [Marie - Anne]124-marie - anne , would look all the better for a little rouge ! "[1595-the old lady] [She]1595-the old lady spoke in a high , quavering voice . [The Duchesse]1547-the duchesse smiled . [[Her]1547-the duchesse brother]1513-her brother had always been [the old Marquise]1601-the old marquise 's favourite . " But [I]1547-the duchesse should feel so ashamed if it came off , "[1547-the duchesse] [she]1547-the duchesse said lightly ; " if , for instance , [I]1547-the duchesse felt one of [my]1547-the duchesse cheeks growing pale while the other remained bright red ? "[1547-the duchesse] " That would never happen if [you]67-sylvia used what [I]1547-the duchesse have often told [you]67-sylvia is the only rouge [a lady]2887-a lady should use , that is , the sap of the geranium blossom — that gives an absolutely natural tint to the skin , and [[my]1547-the duchesse own dear mother]3430-my own dear mother always used it . [You]67-sylvia remember how [Louis XVIII]131-louis xviii . complimented [her]3430-my own dear mother on [her]3430-my own dear mother beautiful complexion at the first Royal ball held after the Restoration ? Well , [the Sovereign]3431-the sovereign 's gracious words were entirely owing to the geranium blossom ! "[1547-the duchesse] The day after [her]1595-the old lady memorable expedition to [Paris]1-paris opened pleasantly for [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia , though it was odd how dull and lifeless [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac seemed to be without [Count Paul]94-count paul . But [he]94-count paul would be back to - morrow , and in the morning of the next day [they]1603-they were to begin riding together . Again and again [she]67-sylvia went over in retrospect every moment of the two hours [she]67-sylvia had spent in [that great house in [the Faubourg St. Germain]6-the faubourg st. germain]1604-that great house in the faubourg st. germain . How kind [these two ladies]1605-these two ladies had been to [her]67-sylvia , [[Paul]94-count paul 's gentle sister]1606-paul 's gentle sister and [[his]94-count paul stately little fairy - like godmother]1607-his stately little fairy - like godmother ! But [the Duchesse]132-the duchesse 's manner had been very formal , almost solemn ; and as for the other — [Sylvia]67-sylvia could still feel the dim , yet terribly searching , eyes fixed on [her]67-sylvia face , and [she]67-sylvia wondered nervously what sort of effect [she]67-sylvia had produced on [the old Marquise]130-the old marquise . Meanwhile , [she]67-sylvia felt that now was the time to see something of [Anna Wolsky]72-anna . The long afternoon and evening stretching before [her]67-sylvia seemed likely to be very dull , and so [she]67-sylvia wrote a little note and asked [Anna]72-anna if [she]72-anna would care for a long expedition in [the Forest of Montmorency]42-the forest of montmorency . It was the sort of thing [Anna]72-anna always said bored [her]67-sylvia , but as [she]67-sylvia was not going to [the Casino]2652-the casino a drive would surely be better than doing nothing . And now [Sylvia]67-sylvia , sitting idly by [her]67-sylvia bed - room window , was awaiting [Anna]72-anna 's answer to [her]72-anna note . [She]72-anna had sent it , just before [she]72-anna went down to luncheon , by [a commissionaire]1609-a commissionaire , to [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait , and the answer ought to have come ere now . After [their]1610-their drive [she]72-anna and [Anna]72-anna might call on [the Wachners]114-the wachners and offer to take [them]114-the wachners to [the Casino]2652-the casino ; and with the thought of [the Wachners]114-the wachners there came over [Sylvia]67-sylvia a regret that [the Comte de Virieu]99-the comte de virieu was so fastidious . [He]99-the comte de virieu seemed to detest [the Wachners]114-the wachners ! When [he]99-the comte de virieu met [them]114-the wachners at [the Casino]2652-the casino , the most [he]99-the comte de virieu would do was to incline [his]99-the comte de virieu head coldly towards [them]114-the wachners . Who could wonder that [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia spoke so disagreeably of [him]99-the comte de virieu ? [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's nature was very loyal , and now [she]67-sylvia reminded [herself]67-sylvia that [this couple]1613-this couple , for whom [Count Paul]94-count paul seemed to have an instinctive dislike , were good - natured and kindly . [She]67-sylvia must ever remember gratefully how helpful [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia had been during the first few days [she]67-sylvia and [Anna]72-anna had been at [Lacville]20-lacville , in showing [them]114-the wachners the little ways about [the place]211-the place , and in explaining to [them]114-the wachners all sorts of things about [the Casino]2652-the casino . And how kindly [the Wachners]114-the wachners had pressed [Anna]72-anna yesterday to have supper with [them]114-the wachners during [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's absence in [Paris]1-paris ! There came a knock at the door , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia jumped up from [her]67-sylvia chair . No doubt this was [Anna]72-anna [herself]72-anna in response to the note . " Come in , "[72-anna] [she]72-anna cried out , in English . There was a pause , and another knock . Then it was not [Anna]72-anna ? " Entrez ! "[72-anna] [The commissionaire by whom [Sylvia]67-sylvia]1616-the commissionaire by whom sylvia had sent [her]67-sylvia note to [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky walked into [the room]194-the room . "[67-sylvia] [Sylvia]67-sylvia looked up . " Partie ? "[67-sylvia] The word puzzled [her]67-sylvia . Surely it should have been " Sortie . "[1620-the commissionaire] [She]67-sylvia paid [him]185-the man , and went [downstairs]203-downstairs hurriedly . What an extraordinary mistake ! If [Anna]72-anna had gone into [Paris]1-paris for the day , the only thing to do was to go for a drive alone . The prospect was not exhilarating , but it would be better than staying [indoors]1623-indoors , or even in [the garden]2749-the garden by [herself]67-sylvia , all afternoon . [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt rather troubled and uncomfortable as [she]67-sylvia got into [the open motor]1625-the open motor . Somehow [she]67-sylvia had counted on seeing [Anna]72-anna to - day . [She]67-sylvia remembered [[her]67-sylvia friend]202-her friend 's last words to [her]67-sylvia . [They]1627-they had been kind , tender words , and though [Anna]72-anna did not approve of [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's friendship for [Paul de Virieu]94-count paul , [she]72-anna had spoken in a very understanding , sympathetic way , almost as [a loving mother]1628-a loving mother might have spoken . It was odd of [Anna]72-anna not to have left word [she]72-anna was going to [Paris]1-paris for the day . In any case , [the Wachners]114-the wachners would know when [Anna]72-anna would be back . It was with [them]114-the wachners that [she]67-sylvia had had supper yesterday evening—. " [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia ! [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia ! "[67-sylvia] [she]67-sylvia cried out eagerly , and [the car]1631-the car drew up with a jerk . [[Her]67-sylvia morose husband]1643-her morose husband very seldom allowed [her]67-sylvia to take [a cab]1644-a cab . Something of [a philosopher]230-a philosopher was [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia , always accepting with eager , out - stretched hands that with which [the gods]1647-the gods provided [her]67-sylvia . "[67-sylvia] [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt rather disappointed . [We]3464-we quite feared something must have happened to [her]73-madame wolsky . "[135-madame malfait] " Will [you]135-madame malfait kindly show [me]67-sylvia the letter [she]73-madame wolsky left for [you]135-madame malfait ? "[67-sylvia] said [Sylvia]67-sylvia . Without speaking , [Madame Malfait]135-madame malfait bent down over [her]135-madame malfait table , and then held out a piece of notepaper on which were written the words : [Madame Malfait]135-madame malfait , — Being unexpectedly obliged to leave [Lacville]20-lacville , [I]0-i enclose herewith 200 francs . Please pay what is owing to [you]135-madame malfait out of it , and distribute the rest among [the servants]1660-the servants . [I]0-i will send [you]135-madame malfait word where to forward [my]0-i luggage in a day or two . [Sylvia]67-sylvia stared reflectively at the open letter . [Anna]72-anna had not even signed [her]72-anna name . The few lines were very clear , written in a large , decided handwriting , considerably larger , or so it seemed to [Sylvia]67-sylvia , than what [she]67-sylvia had thought [Anna]72-anna 's ordinary hand to be . But then [the Englishwoman]1141-the englishwoman had not had the opportunity of seeing much of [[her]135-madame malfait Polish friend]1662-her polish friend 's caligraphy . Before [she]67-sylvia had quite finished reading the mysterious letter over a second time , [Madame Malfait]135-madame malfait took it out of [her]67-sylvia hand . But [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia was entirely unused to being snubbed — [pretty young women provided with plenty of money seldom are snubbed]1663-pretty young women provided with plenty of money seldom are snubbed — and so [she]67-sylvia did not turn away and leave [the hall]635-the hall , as [Madame Malfait]135-madame malfait hoped [she]67-sylvia would do . " What a strange thing ! "[67-sylvia] [she]67-sylvia observed , in a troubled tone . " How extraordinary it is that [[my]67-sylvia friend]2528-my friend should have gone away like this , leaving [her]2528-my friend luggage behind [her]2528-my friend ! What can possibly have made [her]2528-my friend want to leave [Lacville]20-lacville in such a hurry ? [She]2528-my friend was actually engaged to have dinner with [[our]3472-our friends]3473-our friends , [Monsieur]3474-monsieur and [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia . Did [she]2528-my friend not send [them]3473-our friends any sort of message , [Madame Malfait]135-madame malfait ? [I]67-sylvia wish [you]135-madame malfait would try and remember what [she]2528-my friend said when [she]2528-my friend went out . "[67-sylvia] [The Frenchwoman]343-the frenchwoman looked at [her]67-sylvia with a curious stare . " If [you]135-madame malfait ask [me]343-the frenchwoman to tell [you]135-madame malfait the truth , [Madame]73-madame wolsky , "[343-the frenchwoman] [she]343-the frenchwoman replied , rather insolently , " [I]343-the frenchwoman have no doubt at all that [[your]73-madame wolsky friend]2563-your friend went to [the Casino]2652-the casino yesterday and lost a great deal of money — that [she]2528-my friend became , in fact , décavée . "[343-the frenchwoman] Then , feeling ashamed , both of [her]67-sylvia rudeness and of [her]67-sylvia frankness , [she]343-the frenchwoman added : " But [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky is [a very honest lady]3477-a very honest lady , that [I]343-the frenchwoman will say for [her]73-madame wolsky . [You]135-madame malfait see , [she]73-madame wolsky left enough money to pay for everything , as well as to provide [[my]343-the frenchwoman servants]3478-my servants with handsome gratuities . That is more than [the last person who left [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait in a hurry troubled to do]3479-the last person who left the pension malfait in a hurry troubled to do ! "[343-the frenchwoman] " But is it not extraordinary that [she]73-madame wolsky left [her]73-madame wolsky luggage , and that [she]73-madame wolsky did not even tell [you]135-madame malfait where [she]73-madame wolsky was going ? "[67-sylvia] repeated [Sylvia]67-sylvia in a worried , dissatisfied tone . " Pardon [me]67-sylvia , [Madame]73-madame wolsky , that is not strange at all ! [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky probably went off to [Paris]1-paris without knowing exactly where [she]73-madame wolsky meant to stay , and [no one]674-no one wants to take luggage with [them]674-no one when [they]674-no one are looking round for [an hotel]2740-an hotel . "[67-sylvia] There was still a tone of covert insolence in [her]1666-she voice , and [she]1666-she went on , " True , [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky has not behaved as badly as [she]73-madame wolsky might have done . "[67-sylvia] And , as [Sylvia]67-sylvia made no answer , " Perhaps it would be well not to say too much concerning [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky having left like this . "[67-sylvia] [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia spoke very quickly , almost breathlessly , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt vaguely uncomfortable . There was , of course , only one person to whom [she]67-sylvia was likely to mention the fact , and that was [Paul de Virieu]99-the comte de virieu . Was it possible that [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia wished to warn [her]67-sylvia against telling [him]99-the comte de virieu of a fact which [he]99-the comte de virieu was sure to discover for [himself]99-the comte de virieu in the course of a day or two ? As [Sylvia]67-sylvia drove away alone from [the station]475-the station , [she]67-sylvia felt exceedingly troubled and unhappy . It was all very well for [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia to take the matter of [Anna Wolsky]72-anna 's disappearance from [Lacville]20-lacville so philosophically . [The Wachners]114-the wachners ' acquaintance with [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky had been really very slight , and [they]114-the wachners naturally knew nothing of [the Polish woman]386-the polish woman 's inner nature and temperament . [Sylvia]67-sylvia told [herself]67-sylvia that [Anna]72-anna must have been in great trouble , and that something very serious must have happened to [her]72-anna , before [she]72-anna could have gone away like this , without saying anything about it . If poor [Anna]72-anna had changed [her]72-anna mind , and gone to [the Casino]2652-the casino the day before , [she]72-anna might , of course , have lost all [her]72-anna winnings and more . [Sylvia]67-sylvia reminded [herself]67-sylvia that it stood to reason that if one could make hundreds of pounds in an hour or two , then one might equally lose hundreds of pounds in the same time . But somehow [she]67-sylvia could hardly believe that [[her]67-sylvia friend]202-her friend had been so foolish . Still , how else to account for [Anna]72-anna 's disappearance , [her]72-anna sudden exit from [Lacville]20-lacville ? [Anna Wolsky]72-anna was [a proud woman]1682-a proud woman , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia suspected that if [she]67-sylvia had come unexpectedly to the end of [her]67-sylvia resources , [she]67-sylvia would have preferred to go away rather than confide [her]67-sylvia trouble to [a new friend]1683-a new friend . Tears slowly filled [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's blue eyes . [She]67-sylvia felt deeply hurt by [Anna]72-anna 's strange conduct . [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia 's warning as to saying as little as possible of the other 's departure from [Lacville]20-lacville had made very little impression on [Sylvia]67-sylvia , yet it so far affected [her]67-sylvia that , instead of telling [Monsieur Polperro]137-monsieur polperro of the fact the moment [she]67-sylvia was back at [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac , [she]67-sylvia went straight up to [[her]67-sylvia own room]1685-her own room . But when there [she]67-sylvia found that [she]67-sylvia could settle down to nothing — neither to a book nor to letters . Since [[her]67-sylvia husband]254-her husband 's death [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's social circle had become much larger , and there were a number of people who enjoyed inviting and meeting [the pretty , wealthy young widow]1687-the pretty , wealthy young widow . [Sylvia]67-sylvia told [herself]67-sylvia with bitter pain , and again the tears sprang to [her]67-sylvia eyes , that [no one in [the wide world]1691-the wide world]1690-no one in the wide world really cared for [her]67-sylvia . [Those people who had been going to [Switzerland]14-switzerland]1692-those people who had been going to switzerland had thrown [her]67-sylvia over without a thought . [Anna Wolsky]72-anna , who had spoken as if [she]72-anna really loved [her]72-anna only a day or two ago , and who had made that love [her]72-anna excuse for a somewhat impertinent interference in [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's private affairs , had left [Lacville]20-lacville without even sending [her]72-anna word that [she]72-anna was leaving ! True , [she]67-sylvia had [a new and a delightful friend]1693-a new and a delightful friend in [Count Paul de Virieu]94-count paul . But what if [Anna]72-anna had been right ? What if [Count Paul]94-count paul were [a dangerous friend]1694-a dangerous friend , or , worse still , only amusing [himself]94-count paul at [her]67-sylvia expense ? True , [he]94-count paul had taken [her]67-sylvia to see [[his]94-count paul sister]3245-his sister ; but that , after all , might not mean very much . [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia went through a very mournful hour . [She]67-sylvia felt terribly depressed and unhappy , and at last , though there was still a considerable time to dinner , [she]67-sylvia went [downstairs]203-downstairs and out into [the garden]2749-the garden with a book . And then , in a moment , everything was changed . From sad , [she]67-sylvia became happy ; from mournful and self - pitying , full of exquisite content . Looking up , [Sylvia]67-sylvia had seen the now familiar figure of [Count Paul de Virieu]94-count paul hurrying towards [her]67-sylvia . How early [he]94-count paul had left [Paris]1-paris ! [She]67-sylvia had understood that [he]94-count paul meant to come back by [the last train]1698-the last train , or more probably to - morrow morning . "[67-sylvia] " Like [everyone else]3531-everyone else , [I]99-the comte de virieu have been to [such people]3532-such people , "[99-the comte de virieu] [he]99-the comte de virieu answered indifferently . " But if [you]99-the comte de virieu ask [my]99-the comte de virieu true opinion — well , no ; [I]99-the comte de virieu am quite sceptical ! There may be something in what [these dealers in hope]3533-these dealers in hope sometimes say , but more often there is nothing . "[94-count paul] [Count Paul]94-count paul hesitated — but [Sylvia]67-sylvia thought that surely it were better to tell the truth . " Yes , "[67-sylvia] [she]67-sylvia said , " [[my]67-sylvia friend]2528-my friend did play , and [she]2528-my friend played rather high . " Ah , but that alters the case very much ! "[1740-the commissioner] [he]1740-the commissioner said . "[143-monsieur malfait] On the way back [the Commissioner of Police]3590-the commissioner of police said gaily , " It is quite clear that [Madame"—he]142-madame"—he[3590-the commissioner of police] turned and bowed courteously to Sylvia—"knows very little of [Lacville]20-lacville , [Monsieur le Comte]144-monsieur le comte ! "[94-count paul] A long week went by , and still no news , no explanation of [her]1773-her abrupt departure from [Lacville]20-lacville , was received from [Anna Wolsky]72-anna ; and [the owners of [the Pension Malfait]2808-the pension malfait]1774-the owners of the pension malfait were still waiting for instructions as to what was to be done with [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky 's luggage , and with the various little personal possessions [she]1773-her had left scattered about [[her]1773-her room]395-her room . But as time went on [she]67-sylvia felt more and more pained and discomfited by [Anna]72-anna 's strange and heartless behaviour to [herself]67-sylvia . Whatever the reason for [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky 's abrupt departure , it would not have taken [her]72-anna a moment to have sent [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia a line — if only to say that [she]72-anna could give no explanation of [her]1773-her extraordinary conduct . Fortunately there were many things to distract [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's thoughts from [Anna Wolsky]72-anna . [She]67-sylvia now began each morning with a two hours ' ride with [Paul de Virieu]94-count paul . [She]67-sylvia had a graceful seat , and had been well taught ; only a little practice , so [the Count]619-the count assured [her]67-sylvia , was needed to make [her]67-sylvia into [a really good horsewoman]1779-a really good horsewoman , the more so that [she]67-sylvia was very fearless . Leaving [the flat plain of [Lacville]20-lacville]1780-the flat plain of lacville far behind [them]1781-them , [they]1781-them would make [their]1781-them way into [the Forest of Montmorency]42-the forest of montmorency , and through to [the wide valley]1782-the wide valley , which is so beautiful and so little known to [most foreign visitors to [Paris]1-paris]1783-most foreign visitors to paris . [The Duchesse d'Eglemont]1330-the duchesse d'eglemont had sent [[her]1330-the duchesse d'eglemont maid]1785-her maid to [Lacville]20-lacville with the riding habit [she]1330-the duchesse d'eglemont was lending [Sylvia]67-sylvia , and by a word [M. Polperro]93-m. polperro let fall , [the Englishwoman]1141-the englishwoman realised , with mingled confusion and amusement , that [the hotel - keeper]449-the hotel - keeper supposed [her]67-sylvia to be [an old and intimate friend of [[Count Paul]94-count paul 's sister]1789-count paul 's sister]1788-an old and intimate friend of count paul 's sister . [The other people in [the hotel]3294-the hotel]1790-the other people in the hotel began to treat [her]67-sylvia with marked cordiality . And so it came to pass that outwardly [the Polish lady]228-the polish lady 's disappearance came to be regarded even by [Sylvia]67-sylvia as having only been a ripple on the pleasant , lazy , agreeable life [she]67-sylvia , [Count Paul]94-count paul , and last , not least , [the Wachners]114-the wachners , were all leading at [Lacville]20-lacville . In fact , as the days went on , only [Mrs. Bailey]71-mrs. bailey [herself]71-mrs. bailey and [that kindly couple]1793-that kindly couple , [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia and [[her]67-sylvia silent husband]1794-her silent husband , seemed to remember that [Anna]72-anna had ever been [there]210-there . During the first days , when [Sylvia]67-sylvia had been really very anxious and troubled , [she]67-sylvia had had cause to be grateful to [the Wachners]114-the wachners for [their]114-the wachners sympathy ; for whereas [Paul de Virieu]94-count paul seemed only interested in [Anna Wolsky]72-anna because [she]67-sylvia , [Sylvia]67-sylvia , [herself]67-sylvia was interested , both [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia and [[her]67-sylvia morose , silent husband]1796-her morose , silent husband showed real concern and distress at the mysterious lack of news . Whenever [Sylvia]67-sylvia saw [them]1793-that kindly couple , and [she]67-sylvia saw [them]1793-that kindly couple daily at [the Casino]2652-the casino , either [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia or [L'Ami Fritz]112-l'ami fritz would ask [her]67-sylvia in an eager , sympathetic voice , " Have [you]67-sylvia had news of [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky ? "[67-sylvia] And then , when [she]67-sylvia shook [her]67-sylvia head sadly , [they]1793-that kindly couple would express — and especially [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia would express — increasing concern and surprise at [Anna]72-anna 's extraordinary silence . " If only [she]72-anna had come to [us]3643-us as [she]72-anna arranged to do ! "[349-the older woman] [the older woman]349-the older woman exclaimed more than once in a regretful tone . " Then , at any rate , [we]3643-us should know something ; [she]72-anna would not have concealed [her]72-anna plans from [us]3643-us entirely ; [we]3643-us were , if [new friends]3644-new friends , yet on such kind , intimate terms with [the dear soul]3645-the dear soul ! "[349-the older woman] And now , as had been the case exactly a week ago , [Sylvia]67-sylvia was resting in [[her]67-sylvia room]395-her room . [She]67-sylvia was sitting just as [she]67-sylvia had then sat , in a chair drawn up close to the window . There had been no ride that morning , for [Paul de Virieu]94-count paul had been obliged to go into [Paris]1-paris for the day . [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt dull and listless . [She]67-sylvia had never before experienced that aching longing for the presence of another human being which in [our]1800-our civilised life is disguised under many names , but which in this case , [Sylvia]67-sylvia [herself]67-sylvia called by that of " friendship . "[67-sylvia] Moreover , [she]67-sylvia had received that morning a letter which had greatly disturbed [her]67-sylvia . It now lay open on [her]67-sylvia lap , for [she]67-sylvia had just read it through again . This letter was quite short , and simply contained the news that [Bill Chester]79-chester , [[her]67-sylvia good friend]1801-her good friend , [sometime lover]803-sometime lover , and [trustee]1293-trustee , was going to [Switzerland]14-switzerland after all , and that [he]79-chester would stop a couple of days in [Paris]1-paris in order to see [her]67-sylvia . It was really very nice of [Bill]79-chester to do this , and a month ago [Sylvia]67-sylvia would have looked forward to seeing [him]79-chester . But now everything was changed , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia could well have dispensed with [Bill Chester]79-chester 's presence . The thought of [Chester]79-chester at [Lacville]20-lacville filled [her]67-sylvia with unease . When [she]67-sylvia had left [[her]67-sylvia English home]1804-her english home two months ago — it seemed more like two years than two months — [she]67-sylvia had felt well disposed to [the young lawyer]1805-the young lawyer , and deep in [her]67-sylvia inmost heart [she]67-sylvia had almost brought [herself]67-sylvia to acknowledge that [she]67-sylvia might very probably in time become [[his]79-chester wife]455-his wife . [She]67-sylvia suspected that [Chester]79-chester had been fond of [her]67-sylvia when [she]67-sylvia was [a girl]546-a girl , at a time when [his]79-chester means would not have justified [him]79-chester in proposing to [her]67-sylvia , for [he]79-chester was one of [those unusual men who think it dishonourable to ask [girls]1809-girls to marry [them]1809-girls unless [they]1809-girls are in a position to keep [a wife]1810-a wife]1808-those unusual men who think it dishonourable to ask girls to marry them unless they are in a position to keep a wife . [She]67-sylvia remembered how [he]79-chester had looked — how set and stern [his]79-chester face had become when [someone]933-someone had suddenly told [him]79-chester in [her]67-sylvia presence of [her]67-sylvia engagement to [George Bailey]77-george bailey , [the middle - aged man who had been so kind to [her]67-sylvia , and yet who had counted for so little in [her]67-sylvia life , though [she]67-sylvia had given [him]79-chester all [she]67-sylvia could of love and duty]1812-the middle - aged man who had been so kind to her , and yet who had counted for so little in her life , though she had given him all she could of love and duty . Since [her]67-sylvia widowhood , so [she]67-sylvia now reminded [herself]67-sylvia remorsefully , [Chester]79-chester had been extraordinarily good to [her]67-sylvia , and [his]79-chester devotion had touched [her]67-sylvia because it was expressed in actions rather than in words , for [he]79-chester was also [the unusual type of man , seldom a romantic type , who scorns , however much in love , to take advantage of a fiduciary position to strengthen [his]79-chester own]1813-the unusual type of man , seldom a romantic type , who scorns , however much in love , to take advantage of a fiduciary position to strengthen his own . The fact that [he]79-chester was [[her]67-sylvia trustee]256-her trustee brought [them]1815-them into frequent conflict . Too often [Bill]79-chester was [the candid friend]1816-the candid friend instead of [the devoted lover]1817-the devoted lover . [Their]1815-them only real quarrel — if quarrel it could be called — had been , as [we]1818-we know , over the purchase of [her]67-sylvia string of pearls . But time , or so [Sylvia]67-sylvia confidently believed , had proved [her]67-sylvia to have been right , for [her]67-sylvia " investment , "[67-sylvia] as [she]67-sylvia always called it to [Bill Chester]79-chester , had improved in value . But though [she]67-sylvia had been right in that comparatively trifling matter , [she]67-sylvia knew that [Chester]79-chester would certainly disapprove of the kind of life — the idle , purposeless , frivolous life — [she]67-sylvia was now leading . Looking out over [the lake]2707-the lake , which , as it was an exceedingly hot , fine day , was already crowded with [boats]1820-boats , [Sylvia]67-sylvia almost made up [her]67-sylvia mind to go back into [Paris]1-paris for two or three days . [Bill]79-chester would think it a very strange thing that [she]67-sylvia was staying here in [Lacville]20-lacville all by [herself]67-sylvia . But the thought of leaving [Lacville]20-lacville just now was very disagreeable to [Sylvia]67-sylvia .... [She]67-sylvia wondered uncomfortably what [[her]67-sylvia trustee]256-her trustee would think of [her]67-sylvia friendship with [Count Paul de Virieu]94-count paul — with [this Frenchman who , when [he]94-count paul was not gambling at [the Casino]2652-the casino , spent every moment of [his]94-count paul time with [her]67-sylvia]1822-this frenchman who , when he was not gambling at the casino , spent every moment of his time with her . But deep in [her]67-sylvia heart [Sylvia]67-sylvia knew well that when [Bill Chester]79-chester was there [Paul de Virieu]94-count paul would draw back ; only when [they]1824-they were really alone together did [he]94-count paul talk eagerly , naturally . In [the dining - room of [the Villa]583-the villa]1825-the dining - room of the villa [he]94-count paul hardly ever spoke to [her]67-sylvia , and when [they]1824-they were both in [the Baccarat - room of the Club]1827-the baccarat - room of the club [he]94-count paul seldom came and stood by [her]67-sylvia side , though when [she]67-sylvia looked up [she]67-sylvia often found [his]94-count paul eyes fixed on [her]67-sylvia with that ardent , absorbed gaze which made [her]67-sylvia heart beat , and [her]67-sylvia cheeks flush with mingled joy and pain . Suddenly , as if [her]67-sylvia thoughts had brought [him]94-count paul [there]210-there , [she]67-sylvia saw [Count Paul]94-count paul 's straight , slim figure turn in from [the road]647-the road through [the gates of [the Villa]583-the villa]1830-the gates of the villa . [He]94-count paul glanced up at [her]67-sylvia window and took off [his]94-count paul hat . [He]94-count paul looked cool , unruffled , and self - possessed , but [her]67-sylvia eager eyes saw a change in [his]94-count paul face . [He]94-count paul looked very grave , and yet oddly happy . Was it possible that [he]94-count paul had news at last of [Anna Wolsky]72-anna ? [He]94-count paul mounted the stone - steps and disappeared into [the house]579-the house ; and [Sylvia]67-sylvia , getting up , began moving restlessly about [[her]67-sylvia room]395-her room . [She]67-sylvia longed to go [downstairs]203-downstairs , and yet a feminine feeling of delicacy restrained [her]67-sylvia from doing so . A great stillness brooded over everything . The heat had sent [everyone]547-everyone [indoors]1623-indoors . [M. Polperro]93-m. polperro , perhaps because of [his]93-m. polperro Southern up - bringing , always took an early afternoon siesta . It looked as if [[his]93-m. polperro servants]1837-his servants followed [his]93-m. polperro example . [The Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac seemed asleep . [Sylvia]67-sylvia went across to the other window , the window overlooking [the large , shady garden]1839-the large , shady garden , and there , glancing down , [she]67-sylvia saw [Count Paul]94-count paul . " Come into [the garden]2749-the garden — , "[94-count paul] [he]94-count paul said softly in English ; and [Sylvia]67-sylvia , leaning over the bar of [her]67-sylvia window , thought [he]94-count paul added the word " [Maud"—but]146-maud"—but[94-count paul] of course that could not have been so , for [her]67-sylvia name , as [the Count]619-the count knew well , was [Sylvia]67-sylvia ! " [I]67-sylvia do n't believe it is half so cool in [the garden]2749-the garden ! "[67-sylvia] [She]67-sylvia gazed down into [his]94-count paul upturned face with innocent coquetry , pretending — only pretending — to hesitate as to what [she]67-sylvia would do in answer to [his]94-count paul invitation . [She]67-sylvia ran down [the broad shallow staircase]1844-the broad shallow staircase very quickly , for it had occurred to [her]67-sylvia that [the Count]619-the count , taking [her]67-sylvia at [her]67-sylvia word , might leave [the garden]2749-the garden , and , sauntering off to [the Casino]2652-the casino , lose [his]619-the count money — for whatever [he]619-the count might be in love , [Count Paul]94-count paul was exceedingly unlucky at cards ! " And then , with one of [his]94-count paul sudden , stiff bows , [the Comte de Virieu]99-the comte de virieu turned on [his]94-count paul heel , leaving [Sylvia]67-sylvia to make [her]67-sylvia way alone to the little wooden gate on which were painted the words "[0-i] Châlet des Muguets . " [Sylvia]67-sylvia pushed open the little white gate of [the Châlet des Muguets]3173-the châlet des muguets and began walking up the path which lay through [the neglected , untidy garden]3688-the neglected , untidy garden . To eyes accustomed to [the exquisitely - kept gardens of [an English country town]3690-an english country town]3689-the exquisitely - kept gardens of an english country town , there was something almost offensive in the sight presented by the high , coarse grass and luxuriant unkemptness of [the place]211-the place , and once more [Sylvia]67-sylvia wondered how [the Wachners]114-the wachners could bear to leave [the land surrounding [[their]114-the wachners temporary home]3693-their temporary home]3692-the land surrounding their temporary home in such a state . But the quaint , fantastic - looking , one - storeyed châlet amused and rather interested [her]67-sylvia , for it was so entirely unlike [any other dwelling with which [she]67-sylvia was acquainted]3694-any other dwelling with which she was acquainted . To - day a deep , hot calm brooded over [the silent house and deserted - looking garden]3695-the silent house and deserted - looking garden ; the chocolate - coloured shutters of [the dining - room]577-the dining - room and [the drawing - room]1194-the drawing - room were closed , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia told [herself]67-sylvia that it would be delightful to pass from the steamy heat outside into [the dimly - lighted , sparsely - furnished little "[0-i] salon]3698-the dimly - lighted , sparsely - furnished little " salon , " there to have a cup of tea and a pleasant chat with [[her]67-sylvia friends]3498-her friends before accompanying [them]3498-her friends in the cool of the early evening to [the Casino]2652-the casino . [Sylvia]67-sylvia always enjoyed talking to [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia . [She]67-sylvia was a little bit ashamed that this was so , for [this cosmopolitan woman]3701-this cosmopolitan woman 's conversation was not always quite refined , but [she]3701-this cosmopolitan woman was good - natured and lively , and [her]3701-this cosmopolitan woman talk was invariably amusing . Above all , [she]67-sylvia knew how to flatter , and after a chat with [Madame Wachner Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia always felt pleased both with [herself]67-sylvia and with [the world]329-the world about [her]67-sylvia . There was very little concerning [the young Englishwoman]305-the young englishwoman 's simple , uneventful life with which [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia was not by now acquainted . [She]67-sylvia was aware for instance , that [Sylvia]67-sylvia had no close relations of [her]67-sylvia own , and that , like [Anna Wolsky]72-anna , [Mrs. Bailey]71-mrs. bailey knew [nobody]3513-nobody — [she]71-mrs. bailey had not even [an acquaintance]3705-an acquaintance — living in [Paris]1-paris . This fact had enlisted to a special degree [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia 's interest and liking for [the two young widows]239-the two young widows . [Sylvia]67-sylvia rang the primitive bell which hung by the door which alone gave access , apart from the windows , to [the Châlet des Muguets]3173-the châlet des muguets . After some moments [the day - servant employed by [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia]3708-the day - servant employed by madame wachner opened the door with the curt words , "[0-i] [Monsieur]2755-monsieur and [Madame]2550-madame are in [Paris]1-paris . " [The woman]311-the woman added , in a rather insolent tone , "[1886-they] [They]1886-they have gone to fetch some money , " and [her]311-the woman manner said plainly enough , "[1886-they] Yes , [[my]0-i master]1887-my master and [mistress]1888-mistress — [silly fools]1889-silly fools — have lost [their]1886-they money at [the Casino]2652-the casino , and now [they]1886-they are gone to get fresh supplies ! " [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt vexed and disappointed . After what had been to [her]67-sylvia a very exciting , agitating conversation with [Count Paul]94-count paul , [she]67-sylvia had unconsciously longed for the cheerful , commonplace talk of [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia . As [she]67-sylvia stood there in the bright sunlight the thought of the long , lonely , hot walk back to [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac became odious to [her]67-sylvia . Why should [she]67-sylvia not go into [the house]579-the house and rest awhile ? The more so that [the Wachners]114-the wachners would almost certainly return [home]400-home very soon . [They]114-the wachners disliked [Paris]1-paris , and never stayed more than a couple of hours on [their]114-the wachners occasional visits [there]210-there . In [her]0-i careful , rather precise French , [she]0-i told [the servant]719-the servant [she]0-i would come in and wait . Perhaps when [Madame]67-sylvia leaves [the house]579-the house [she]67-sylvia will put the key under the mat . " [The woman]311-the woman 's manner altered ; it became at once familiar and servile . " [The servant]719-the servant looked at [her]0-i fixedly , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's face became what it seldom was — very forbidding in expression . " [The Frenchwoman]343-the frenchwoman took up [her]343-the frenchwoman parasol and laid the house key on the table , then , with a "[0-i] Bon jour , [Madame]2550-madame , et encore merci bien ! " [she]343-the frenchwoman noisily closed the door behind [her]343-the frenchwoman . A moment later , [Sylvia]67-sylvia , with a sense of relief , found [herself]67-sylvia in sole possession of the Châlet des Muguets . Even the quietest , [the most commonplace house]3728-the most commonplace house has , as it were , an individuality that sets [it]3728-the most commonplace house apart from [other houses]3729-other houses . And even [those who would deny that proposition]3730-those who would deny that proposition must admit that [every inhabited dwelling]3731-every inhabited dwelling has its own special nationality . [The Châlet des Muguets]3173-the châlet des muguets was typically French and typically suburban ; but where [it]3173-the châlet des muguets differed from [thousands of houses of the same type , dotted round in [the countrysides within easy reach of [Paris]1-paris]3734-the countrysides within easy reach of paris]3733-thousands of houses of the same type , dotted round in the countrysides within easy reach of paris , was that [it]3173-the châlet des muguets was let each year to [a different set of [tenants]3736-tenants]3735-a different set of tenants . In [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's eyes [the queer little place]3737-the queer little place lacked all the elements which go to make a home ; and , sitting there , in [that airless , darkened dining - room]3738-that airless , darkened dining - room , [she]67-sylvia wondered , not for the first time , why [the Wachners]114-the wachners chose to live in such a comfortless way . [She]67-sylvia glanced round [her]67-sylvia with distaste . Everything was not only cheap , but common and tawdry . Still , [the dining - room]577-the dining - room , like [all the other rooms in [the châlet]1339-the châlet]3740-all the other rooms in the châlet , was singularly clean , and almost oppressively neat . There was the round table at which [she]67-sylvia and [Anna Wolsky]72-anna had been so kindly entertained , the ugly buffet or sideboard , and in place of the dull parquet floor [she]67-sylvia remembered on [her]67-sylvia first visit lay an ugly piece of linoleum , of which the pattern printed on the surface simulated a red and blue marble pavement . Once more the change puzzled [her]67-sylvia , perhaps unreasonably . At last [Sylvia]67-sylvia got up from the hard cane chair on which [she]67-sylvia had been sitting . There had come over [her]67-sylvia , in the half - darkness , a very peculiar sensation — an odd feeling that there was something alive in [the room]194-the room . [She]67-sylvia looked down , half expecting to see some small animal crouching under the table , or hiding by the walnut - wood buffet behind [her]67-sylvia . But , no ; nothing but the round table , and the six chairs stiffly placed against the wall , met [her]67-sylvia eyes . And yet , still that feeling that there was in [the room]194-the room some sentient creature besides [herself]67-sylvia persisted . [She]67-sylvia opened the door giving into [the hall]635-the hall , and walked through [the short passage which divided [the house]579-the house into two portions]3745-the short passage which divided the house into two portions , into [the tiny "[0-i] salon]3747-the tiny " salon . " Here also the closed shutters gave [the room]194-the room a curious , eerie look of desolate greyness . But [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's eyes , already accustomed to the half - darkness next door , saw everything perfectly . [The little sitting - room]3749-the little sitting - room looked mean and shabby . There was not a flower , not even a book or a paper , to relieve its prim ugliness . The only ornaments were a gilt clock on the mantelpiece , flanked with two sham Empire candelabra . The shutters were fastened closely , and [the room]194-the room was dreadfully hot and airless . Once more [Sylvia]67-sylvia wondered why [the Wachners]114-the wachners preferred to live in this cheerless way , with [a servant who only came for a few hours each day]3751-a servant who only came for a few hours each day , rather than at [an hotel]2740-an hotel or [boarding - house]3753-boarding - house . And then [she]67-sylvia reminded [herself]67-sylvia that , after all , [the silent , gaunt man]3754-the silent , gaunt man , and [[his]3754-the silent , gaunt man talkative , voluble wife]3755-his talkative , voluble wife , seemed to be on exceptionally good terms [the one with the other]3756-the one with the other . Perhaps [they]114-the wachners really preferred being alone together than in a more peopled atmosphere . While moving aimlessly about [the room]194-the room , [Sylvia]67-sylvia began to feel unaccountably nervous and oppressed . [She]67-sylvia longed to be away from [this still , empty house]3758-this still , empty house , and yet it seemed absurd to leave just as [the Wachners]114-the wachners would be returning [home]400-home . After a few more minutes , however , the quietude , and the having absolutely nothing to do with which to wile away the time , affected [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's nerves . It was , after all , quite possible that [the Wachners]114-the wachners intended to wait in [Paris]1-paris till the heat of the day was over . In that case [they]114-the wachners would not be back till seven o'clock . The best thing [she]67-sylvia could do would be to leave a note inviting [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia and [L'Ami Fritz]112-l'ami fritz to dinner at [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac . [Count Paul]94-count paul was to be in [Paris]1-paris this evening , so [his]94-count paul eyes would not be offended by the sight of [the people of whom [he]94-count paul so disapproved]3761-the people of whom he so disapproved . [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia would probably be glad to dine out , the more so that no proper meal seemed to have been prepared by [that unpleasant day - servant]3762-that unpleasant day - servant . Why , [the woman]311-the woman had not even laid the cloth for [[her]311-the woman employers]3764-her employers ' supper ! [Sylvia]67-sylvia looked instinctively round for paper and envelopes , but there was no writing - table , not even a pencil and paper , in [the little drawing - room]3765-the little drawing - room . How absurd and annoying ! But , stay — somewhere in [the house]579-the house there must be writing materials . Treading softly , and yet hearing [her]67-sylvia footsteps echoing with unpleasant loudness through [the empty house]3767-the empty house , [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia walked past the open door of [the little kitchen]3768-the little kitchen , and so to the end of [the passage]1347-the passage . Then something extraordinary happened . While in the act of opening the door of [[Madame Wachner]67-sylvia 's bed - room]3770-madame wachner 's bed - room , [the young Englishwoman]305-the young englishwoman stopped and caught [her]67-sylvia breath . Again [she]67-sylvia had suddenly experienced that unpleasant , eerie sensation — the sensation that [she]67-sylvia was not alone . But this time the feeling was far more vivid than it had been in [the dining - room]577-the dining - room . So strong , so definite was [Sylvia]67-sylvia 's perception of another presence , and this time of a human presence , in [the still house]3773-the still house , that [she]67-sylvia turned sharply round — But all [she]67-sylvia saw was [the empty passage]3774-the empty passage , cut by a shaft of light thrown from the open door of [the kitchen]3190-the kitchen , stretching its short length down to [the entrance hall]3776-the entrance hall . Making a determined effort over what [she]67-sylvia could but suppose to be [her]67-sylvia nerves , [she]67-sylvia walked through into [[the Wachners]114-the wachners ' bed - room]3777-the wachners ' bed - room . [It]3777-the wachners ' bed - room was very bare and singularly poorly furnished , at least to English eyes , but [it]3777-the wachners ' bed - room was pleasantly cool after [the drawing - room]1194-the drawing - room . [She]67-sylvia walked across to the window , and , drawing aside the muslin curtains , looked out . Beyond the patch of shade thrown by [the house]579-the house the sun beat down on a ragged , unkempt lawn , but across [the lawn]3780-the lawn [she]67-sylvia noticed , much more particularly than [she]67-sylvia had done on the two former occasions when [she]67-sylvia had been in [the house]579-the house , that there lay a thick grove of chestnut trees just beyond [the grounds of [the Châlet des Muguets]3173-the châlet des muguets]3782-the grounds of the châlet des muguets . A hedge separated [the lawn]3780-the lawn from the wood , but like everything else in [the little property]3785-the little property [it]3777-the wachners ' bed - room had been neglected , and there were large gaps in [it]3777-the wachners ' bed - room . [She]67-sylvia turned away from the window — Yes , there , at last , was what [she]67-sylvia had come into [this room]3786-this room to seek ! Close to the broad , low bed was a writing - table , or , rather , a deal table , covered with a turkey red cloth , on which lay a large sheet of ink - stained , white blotting - paper . Flanking the blotting - paper was a pile of [Monsieur Wachner]111-monsieur wachner 's little red books — the books in which [he]111-monsieur wachner so carefully noted the turns of the game at [the Casino]2652-the casino , and which served [him]111-monsieur wachner as the basis of [his]111-monsieur wachner elaborate gambling "[0-i] systems . " [Sylvia]67-sylvia went up to the writing - table , and , bending over it , began looking for some notepaper . But there was nothing of the sort to be seen ; neither paper nor envelopes lay on the table . This was the more absurd , as there were several pens , and an inkpot filled to the brim . [She]67-sylvia told [herself]67-sylvia that the only thing to do was to tear a blank leaf out of one of [L'Ami Fritz]112-l'ami fritz 's note - books , and on it write [her]67-sylvia message of invitation . If [she]67-sylvia left the little sheet of paper propped up on the dining - table , [the Wachners]114-the wachners would be sure to see it . [She]67-sylvia took up the newest - looking of the red note - books , and as [she]67-sylvia opened it [she]67-sylvia suddenly felt , and for the third time , that there was a living presence close to [her]67-sylvia — and this time that it was that of [Anna Wolsky]72-anna ! It was an extraordinary sensation — vivid , uncanny , terrifying — the more so that [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia not only believed [herself]67-sylvia to be alone in [the house]579-the house , but supposed [Anna]72-anna to be far from [Lacville]20-lacville .... Fortunately , this unnerving and terrifying impression of an unseen and yet real presence did not endure ; and , as [she]67-sylvia focussed [her]67-sylvia eyes on the open book [she]67-sylvia held in [her]67-sylvia hand , it became fainter and fainter , while [she]67-sylvia realised , with a keen sense of relief , what it was that had brought the presence of [[her]67-sylvia absent friend]3789-her absent friend so very near to [her]67-sylvia . There , actually lying open before [her]67-sylvia , between two leaves of the little note - book , was a letter signed by [Anna Wolsky]72-anna ! It was a short note , in French , apparently an answer to one [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia had sent reminding [her]67-sylvia of [her]67-sylvia engagement . It was odd that [the Wachners]114-the wachners had said nothing of this note , for it made [Anna]72-anna 's conduct seem stranger than ever . Opposite the page on which lay the little letter , [Monsieur Wachner]111-monsieur wachner had amused [himself]111-monsieur wachner by trying to imitate [Anna]72-anna 's angular handwriting . [Sylvia]67-sylvia tore out one of the blank pages , and then [she]67-sylvia put the note - book and its enclosure back on the table . [She]67-sylvia felt vaguely touched by the fact that [the Wachners]114-the wachners had kept [[her]67-sylvia friend]202-her friend 's last letter ; [they]114-the wachners alone , so [she]67-sylvia reminded [herself]67-sylvia , had been really sorry and concerned at [Anna]72-anna 's sudden departure from [the place]211-the place . [They]114-the wachners also , like [Sylvia]67-sylvia [herself]67-sylvia , had been pained that [Madame Wolsky]73-madame wolsky had not cared to say good - bye to [them]114-the wachners . [She]67-sylvia scribbled a few lines on the scrap of paper , and then , quickly making [her]67-sylvia way to [the dining - room]577-the dining - room , [she]67-sylvia placed [her]67-sylvia unconventional invitation on the round table , and went out into [the hall]635-the hall . As [she]67-sylvia opened the front door of [the Châlet des Muguets]3173-the châlet des muguets [Sylvia]67-sylvia was met by a blast of hot air . [She]67-sylvia looked out dubiously . [She]67-sylvia was thoroughly unnerved — as [she]67-sylvia expressed it to [herself]67-sylvia , "[0-i] upset . " Feeling as [she]67-sylvia now felt , walking back through the heat would be intolerable . For the first time [Lacville]20-lacville became utterly distasteful to [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia . [She]20-lacville asked [herself]20-lacville , with a kind of surprise , of self - rebuke , why [she]67-sylvia was [there]210-there — away from [[her]20-lacville own country]362-her own country and [[her]20-lacville own people]3797-her own people ? With a choking sensation in [her]20-lacville throat [she]20-lacville told [herself]20-lacville that it would be very comfortable to see once more [the tall , broad figure of [Bill Chester]79-chester]3798-the tall , broad figure of bill chester , and to hear [his]79-chester good , gruff English voice again . [She]20-lacville stepped out of [the house]579-the house , and put up [her]20-lacville white parasol . It was still dreadfully hot , but to the left , across [the lawn]3780-the lawn , lay the cool depths of the chestnut wood . Why not go over there and rest in the shade ? Hurrying across the scorched grass to the place where there was an opening in the rough hedge , [she]20-lacville found [herself]20-lacville , a moment later , plunged in the grateful green twilight created by high trees . It was delightfully quiet and still in [the wood]3801-the wood , and [Sylvia]67-sylvia wondered vaguely why [the Wachners]114-the wachners never took [their]114-the wachners tea out there . But [foreigners]209-foreigners are very law - abiding , or so [she]67-sylvia supposed , and the wood , if [a piece of [no - man]3804-no - man 's land]3803-a piece of no - man 's land , was for sale . Up [a path]3805-a path [she]67-sylvia could see the back of a large board . It was clear that [this pretty bit of woodland]3806-this pretty bit of woodland would have been turned into [villa plots]3807-villa plots long ago had [it]3806-this pretty bit of woodland been nearer to [a road]3808-a road . But [it]3806-this pretty bit of woodland was still [a stretch of primeval forest]3809-a stretch of primeval forest . Here and there , amid the tufts of grass , lay the husks of last autumn 's chestnuts . [Sylvia]67-sylvia slowly followed the little zigzag way which cut across the wood , and then , desiring to sit down for awhile , [she]20-lacville struck off to the right , towards a spot where [she]20-lacville saw that the brambles and the undergrowth had been cleared away . Even here , where in summer the sun never penetrated , the tufts of coarse grass were dried up by the heat . [She]67-sylvia glanced down ; no , there was no fear that the hard , dry ground would stain [her]67-sylvia pretty cotton frock . And then , as [she]67-sylvia sat there , [Sylvia]67-sylvia gradually became aware that close to [her]67-sylvia , where the undergrowth began again , the earth had recently been disturbed . Over an irregular patch of about [a yard square the sods]3810-a yard square the sods had been dug up , and then planted again . The thought passed through [her]67-sylvia mind that [children]288-children must have been playing [there]210-there , and that [they]288-children had made a rude attempt to destroy [their]288-children handiwork , or rather to prevent its being noticed , by placing the branch of a tree across the little plot of ground where the earth had been disturbed . It was this broken branch , of which the leaves had shrivelled up , that had first drawn [her]67-sylvia attention to the fact that [someone]933-someone must have been there , and recently . [Her]67-sylvia thoughts wandered off to [Bill Chester]79-chester . [He]79-chester was now actually journeying towards [her]67-sylvia as fast as [boat and train]3814-boat and train could bring [him]79-chester ; in a couple of hours [he]79-chester would be in [Paris]1-paris , and then , perhaps , [he]79-chester would come out to [Lacville]20-lacville in time for dinner . [Sylvia]67-sylvia had not been able to get [a room for [him]79-chester in [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac]3815-a room for him in the villa du lac , but [she]67-sylvia had engaged one in [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait — where [she]67-sylvia had been able to secure [the apartment which had been occupied by [Anna Wolsky]72-anna , whose things had only just been moved out of [it]3817-the apartment which had been occupied by anna wolsky , whose things had only just been moved out of it]3817-the apartment which had been occupied by anna wolsky , whose things had only just been moved out of it . [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt jealous for the good fame of [Lacville]20-lacville . Out in the open air [her]67-sylvia spirits had recovered [their]3819-their balance ; [she]67-sylvia told [herself]67-sylvia that [she]67-sylvia had been very happy here — singularly , extraordinarily happy .... Of course it was a pity when [people]398-people lost more money than [they]398-people could afford at [the Casino]2652-the casino ; but even in [England]8-england [people]398-people betted — [the poor]3823-the poor , so [she]67-sylvia had been told , risked all [their]3823-the poor spare pence on horse racing , and [the others]1266-the others , [those who could afford it]3825-those who could afford it , went to [Monte Carlo]9-monte carlo , or stayed at [home]400-home and played bridge ! After all , where was the difference ? And then , with a shock of surprise which sent the blood to [his]152-chester cheeks , [Chester]152-chester suddenly saw that [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia was sitting nearly opposite to where [he]152-chester [himself]152-chester was standing . There are certain scenes , certain human groupings of [individuals]3940-individuals , which remain fixed for ever against the screen of memory . [Bill Chester]79-chester will never forget the sight which was presented to [him]152-chester in [the Lacville Casino]3484-the lacville casino by the particular group on which [his]152-chester tired eyes became focussed with growing amazement and attention . [Sylvia]67-sylvia was sitting at the baccarat table next to [the man who was acting as [Banker]1460-banker]3942-the man who was acting as banker . [She]67-sylvia was evidently absorbed in the fortunes of the game , and [she]67-sylvia followed the slow falling of the fateful cards with rather feverish intentness . [Her]67-sylvia small gloved hands rested on the table , one of them loosely holding a tiny ivory rake ; and on a bank - note spread open on the green cloth before [her]67-sylvia were two neat piles of gold , the one composed of twenty - franc , the other of ten - franc pieces . [Chester]79-chester , with a strange feeling of fear and anger clutching at [his]79-chester heart , told [himself]79-chester that [he]79-chester had never seen [Sylvia]67-sylvia look as [she]67-sylvia looked to - night . [She]67-sylvia was more than pretty — [she]67-sylvia was lovely , and above all , alive — vividly alive . There was a bright colour on [her]67-sylvia cheek , and a soft light shining in [her]67-sylvia eyes . The row of pearls which had occasioned the only serious difference which had ever arisen between them , rose and fell softly on the bosom of [her]67-sylvia black lace dress . [Chester]79-chester also gradually became aware that [[his]79-chester beautiful friend]3944-his beautiful friend and [client]3945-client formed a centre of attraction to [those standing round the gambling - table]3946-those standing round the gambling - table . Both [the men]3925-the men and [the women]3948-the women stared at [her]67-sylvia , some enviously , but more with kindly admiration , for beauty is sure of its tribute in [any French audience]3949-any french audience , and [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia to - night looked radiantly lovely — lovely and yet surely unhappy and ill - at - ease . Well might [she]67-sylvia look both in such a place and among [such a crew]3950-such a crew ! So [the English lawyer]3893-the english lawyer angrily told [himself]3893-the english lawyer . Now and again [she]67-sylvia turned and spoke in an eager , intimate fashion to [a man sitting next [her]67-sylvia on [her]67-sylvia left]3952-a man sitting next her on her left . [[Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's companion]3954-sylvia bailey 's companion was obviously [a Frenchman]227-a frenchman , or so [Chester]79-chester felt sure , for now [he]79-chester found [himself]79-chester concentrating [his]79-chester attention on [[Mrs. Bailey]71-mrs. bailey 's neighbour]3956-mrs. bailey 's neighbour rather than on [her]67-sylvia . [This man]3953-this man , to whom [she]67-sylvia kept turning and speaking in a low , earnest tone , was slim and fair , and what could be seen of [his]3953-this man evening clothes fitted scrupulously well . And then , it was all so deliberate ! [Chester]79-chester had once seen [a man whom [he]79-chester greatly respected drunk]3997-a man whom he greatly respected drunk , and the sight had ever remained with [him]79-chester . " [She]0-i sighed , a long , sentimental sigh , and looked across , affectionately , at [L'Ami Fritz]112-l'ami fritz . " [He]829-the landlord put the candle down , and bowed [himself]829-the landlord out of [the room]194-the room . [Chester]152-chester looked round [the large , bare sleeping chamber in which [he]152-chester found [himself]152-chester with the agreeable feeling that [his]152-chester long , hot , exciting day was now at an end]4098-the large , bare sleeping chamber in which he found himself with the agreeable feeling that his long , hot , exciting day was now at an end . Yes , [it]2866-this was [a pleasant room]4099-a pleasant room — bare , and yet furnished with everything essential to comfort . Thus there was a good big , roomy arm - chair , a writing - table , and a clock , of which the hands now pointed to a quarter to one o'clock . The broad , low bed , pushed back into an alcove as is the French fashion , looked delightfully cool and inviting by the light of [his]152-chester one candle . When [M. Malfait]103-m. malfait had shown [him]152-chester into [the room]194-the room the window was wide open to the hot , starless night , but [the landlord]829-the landlord , though [he]829-the landlord had left the window open , had drawn the thick curtains across it . That was all right ; [Chester]152-chester had no wish to be wakened at five in the morning by the sunlight streaming into [the room]194-the room . [He]152-chester meant to have a really long rest . [He]152-chester was too tired to think — too tired to do anything but turn in . And then an odd thing happened . [Chester]152-chester 's brain was so thoroughly awake , [he]152-chester had become so over - excited , that [he]152-chester could not , try as [he]152-chester might , fall asleep . [He]152-chester lay awake tossing about hour after hour . And then , when at last [he]152-chester did fall into a heavy , troubled slumber , [he]152-chester was disturbed by extraordinary and unpleasant dreams — nightmares in which [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia seemed to play a part . At last [he]152-chester roused [himself]152-chester and pulled back the curtains from across the window . It was already dawn , but [he]152-chester thought the cool morning air might induce sleep , and for a while , lying on [his]152-chester side away from the light , [he]152-chester did doze lightly . Quite suddenly [he]152-chester was awakened by the sensation , nay , the knowledge , that there was someone in [the room]194-the room ! So vivid was this feeling of unwished - for companionship that [he]152-chester got up and looked in the shadowed recess of the alcove in which stood [his]152-chester bed ; but , of course , there was [no one there]4104-no one there . In fact there would not have been space there for [any grown - up person]4105-any grown - up person to squeeze into . [He]152-chester told [himself]152-chester that what [he]152-chester had heard — if [he]152-chester had heard anything — was [someone]933-someone bringing [him]152-chester [his]152-chester coffee and rolls , and that [the servant]719-the servant had probably been trying to attract [his]152-chester attention , for , following [his]152-chester prudent custom , [he]152-chester had locked [his]152-chester door the night before . [He]152-chester unlocked the door and looked out , staring this way and that along [the empty passage]3774-the empty passage . But no , in spite of the now - risen sun , it was still early morning ; [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait was sunk in sleep . [Chester]152-chester went back to bed . [He]152-chester felt tired , disturbed , uneasy ; sleep was out of the question ; so [he]152-chester lay back , and with widely - open eyes , began to think of [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia and of the strange events of the night before . [He]152-chester lived again the long hour [he]152-chester had spent at [the Casino]46-the casino . [He]152-chester could almost smell the odd , sweet , stuffy smell of [the Baccarat Room]697-the baccarat room , and there rose before [him]152-chester [its]697-the baccarat room queer , varied inmates . [He]152-chester visioned distinctly [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia as [he]152-chester had suddenly seen [her]67-sylvia , sitting before the green cloth , with [her]67-sylvia money piled up before [her]67-sylvia , and a look of eager interest and absorption on [her]67-sylvia face . There had always been in [Sylvia]67-sylvia something a little rebellious , a touch of individuality which made [her]67-sylvia unlike [the other women [he]152-chester knew]4110-the other women he knew , and which fascinated and attracted [him]152-chester . [She]67-sylvia was [a woman who generally knew [her]67-sylvia own mind , and who had [her]67-sylvia own ideas of right and wrong]4111-a woman who generally knew her own mind , and who had her own ideas of right and wrong . Lying there , [he]152-chester remembered how determined [she]67-sylvia had been about those pearls .... [Chester]152-chester 's thoughts took a softer turn . How very , very pretty [she]67-sylvia had looked last evening — more than pretty — lovelier than [he]152-chester had ever seen [her]67-sylvia . There seemed to be new depths in [her]67-sylvia blue eyes . But [Chester]152-chester was shrewd enough to know that [Sylvia]67-sylvia had felt ashamed to be caught by [him]152-chester gambling — gambling , too , in such very mixed company . Well , [she]67-sylvia would soon be leaving [Lacville]20-lacville ! What a pity [those friends of hers]4112-those friends of hers had given up [their]4112-those friends of hers Swiss holiday ! It would have been so jolly if [they]4112-those friends of hers could have gone on [there]210-there together . [He]152-chester got tired of lying in bed . What a long night , as well as a very short night , it had been ! [He]152-chester rose and made [his]152-chester way down to [the primitive bath - room]4114-the primitive bath - room . It would be delightful to have any sort of bath , and the huge zinc basin had its points — As [Chester]152-chester went quickly back to [[his]152-chester room]3266-his room , instead of feeling refreshed after [his]152-chester bath , [he]152-chester again experienced the disagreeable sensation that [he]152-chester was not alone . This time [he]152-chester felt as if [he]152-chester were being accompanied by an invisible presence . It was a very extraordinary and a most unpleasant feeling , one which [Chester]152-chester had never experienced before , and it made [him]152-chester afraid — afraid [he]152-chester knew not of what . Being the manner of man [he]152-chester was , [he]152-chester began to think that [he]152-chester must be ill — that there must be something the matter with [his]152-chester nerves . Had [he]152-chester been at [home]400-home , in [Market Dalling]10-market dalling , [he]152-chester would have gone to [a doctor]4117-a doctor without loss of time . Long afterwards , when [people]398-people used to speak before [him]152-chester of [haunted houses]4119-haunted houses , [Bill Chester]79-chester would remember the Pension Malfait and the extraordinary sensations [he]152-chester had experienced [there]210-there — sensations the more extraordinary that there was nothing to account for them . But [Chester]79-chester never told [anyone]2713-anyone of [his]79-chester experiences , and indeed there was nothing to tell . [He]79-chester never saw anything , [he]79-chester never even heard anything , but now and again , especially when [he]79-chester was lying awake at night and in the early morning , [the lawyer]4000-the lawyer felt as if [some other entity]4123-some other entity was struggling to communicate with [him]79-chester and could not do so .... The whole time [he]79-chester was [there]210-there — and [he]79-chester stayed on at [Lacville]20-lacville , as [we]4125-we shall see , rather longer than [he]79-chester at first intended — [Chester]79-chester never felt , when in [[his]79-chester room at [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait]4126-his room at the pension malfait really alone , and sometimes the impression became almost intolerably vivid . But the longest night , the most haunted night , and [Chester]79-chester 's night had indeed been haunted , comes to an end at last . After [he]79-chester had had another bath and a good breakfast [he]79-chester felt [a very different man]4127-a very different man to what [he]79-chester had done three or four hours ago , lying awake in the sinister , companioned atmosphere of [[his]79-chester bed - room at [the Pension Malfait]34-the pension malfait]4128-his bed - room at the pension malfait . Telling [[his]79-chester courteous landlord]4129-his courteous landlord that [he]79-chester would not be in to luncheon , [Chester]79-chester left [the house]579-the house , and as it was still far too early to seek out [Sylvia]67-sylvia , [he]79-chester struck out , with the aid of the little pocket - map of [the environs of [Paris]1-paris with which [he]79-chester had been careful to provide [himself]79-chester]4131-the environs of paris with which he had been careful to provide himself , towards [the open country]3125-the open country . And as [he]79-chester swung quickly along , feeling once more tired and depressed , [the Englishman]3874-the englishman wondered more and more why [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia cared to stay in [such a place as [Lacville]20-lacville]1701-such a place as lacville . It struck [him]79-chester as [neither town]4135-neither town nor [country]507-country — more like [an unfinished suburb]4137-an unfinished suburb than anything else , with almost every piece of spare land up for sale . [He]79-chester walked on and on till at last [he]79-chester came to the edge of a great stretch of what looked like primeval woodland . This surely must be part of [the famous Forest of [Montmorency]21-montmorency]4138-the famous forest of montmorency , which [his]79-chester guide - book mentioned as being [the great attraction of [Lacville]20-lacville]4139-the great attraction of lacville ? [He]79-chester wondered cynically whether [Sylvia]67-sylvia had ever been so far , and then [he]79-chester plunged into [the wood]3801-the wood , along one of the ordered alleys which to [his]79-chester English eyes looked so little forest - like , and yet which made walking there very pleasant . Suddenly there fell on [his]79-chester ear the sound of horses trotting quickly . [He]79-chester looked round , and some hundred yards or so to [his]79-chester right , at a place where [four roads met under high arching trees]4141-four roads met under high arching trees , [he]79-chester saw [two riders]4142-two riders , [a man]234-a man and [a woman]309-a woman , pass by . [They]4142-two riders had checked [their]4142-two riders horses to a walk , and as [their]4142-two riders voices floated over to [him]79-chester , [the woman]311-the woman 's voice seemed extraordinarily , almost absurdly , familiar — in fact , [he]79-chester could have sworn it was [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia 's voice . [Chester]79-chester stopped in [his]79-chester walk and shrugged [his]79-chester shoulders impatiently . [She]67-sylvia must indeed be dwelling in [his]79-chester thoughts if [he]79-chester thus involuntarily evoked [her]67-sylvia presence where [she]67-sylvia could by no stretch of possibility be . But that wandering echo brought [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia very near to [Chester]79-chester , and once more [he]79-chester recalled [her]67-sylvia as [he]79-chester had seen [her]67-sylvia sitting at the gambling table the night before . In grotesque juxtaposition [he]79-chester remembered , together with that picture of [Sylvia]67-sylvia as [he]79-chester had seen [her]67-sylvia last night , the case of [a respectable old lady , named [Mrs. Meeks]158-mrs. meeks]4146-a respectable old lady , named mrs. meeks , [the widow of a clergyman who had had a living in [the vicinity of [Market Dalling]10-market dalling]4148-the vicinity of market dalling]4147-the widow of a clergyman who had had a living in the vicinity of market dalling . Not long after [[her]4146-a respectable old lady , named mrs. meeks husband]254-her husband 's death [this old lady]4022-this old lady — [she]4146-a respectable old lady , named mrs. meeks had about three hundred a year , and [Chester]79-chester had charge of [her]4146-a respectable old lady , named mrs. meeks money matters — went abroad for a few weeks to [Mentone]23-mentone . [She]158-mrs. meeks now lived entirely at [Monte Carlo]9-monte carlo in [one small room]4152-one small room . [He]79-chester could not help remembering now the kind of remarks that were made by [the more prosperous inhabitants of [Market Dalling]10-market dalling]4153-the more prosperous inhabitants of market dalling , [[his]79-chester fellow citizens]4154-his fellow citizens , when [they]4153-the more prosperous inhabitants of market dalling went off for a short holiday to [the South]63-the south , in January or February . [Chester]79-chester knew that one of the first things said to [him]79-chester after the return of [such people]3532-such people would be , "[2045-a charming polish lady] Who d'you think [I]0-i saw at [Monte Carlo]9-monte carlo ? " And now [he]79-chester told [himself]79-chester ruefully that it would be enough to make [honest George Bailey]77-george bailey turn in [his]254-her husband grave could [he]79-chester see [his]79-chester pretty , sheltered Sylvia sitting in [the Casino at [Lacville]20-lacville]4157-the casino at lacville , surrounded by the riffraff collected [there last night]4158-there last night , and actually taking an active part in the game as well as risking [her]158-mrs. meeks money with business - like intentness . [He]79-chester wondered if [he]79-chester could persuade [Sylvia]67-sylvia to leave [Lacville]20-lacville soon . In any case [he]79-chester would [himself]79-chester stay on [here]2519-here three or four days — [he]79-chester had meant only to stay twenty - four hours , for [he]79-chester was on [his]79-chester way to join a friend whose Swiss holiday was limited . The sensible thing for [Sylvia]67-sylvia to do would be to go back to [England]8-england . [Chester]79-chester reached [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac at half - past eleven and as [he]79-chester went out into [the charming garden]818-the charming garden where [he]79-chester was told [he]79-chester would find [Mrs. Bailey]71-mrs. bailey [he]79-chester told [himself]79-chester that [Lacville]20-lacville was not without some innocent attractions . But [Mrs. Bailey]71-mrs. bailey was not alone in [this lovely garden]4162-this lovely garden . " And [Sylvia Bailey]67-sylvia was amused , as well as rather touched , to see the preparations which had been made in [the little dining - room]4237-the little dining - room for the entertainment of [Bill Chester]79-chester and of [herself]67-sylvia . In the middle of the round table which had looked so bare yesterday was a bowl of white roses — roses that had never grown in [the untidy garden outside]4238-the untidy garden outside . Two dessert dishes were heaped up with delicious cakes — the cakes for which French pastrycooks are justly famed . There was also a basin full of the Alpine strawberries which [Sylvia]67-sylvia loved , and of which [she]67-sylvia always ordered a goodly supply at [the Villa du Lac]2645-the villa du lac . [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia had even remembered to provide the thick cream , which , to a foreign taste , spoils the delicate flavour of strawberries . It was as if [he]152-chester had come across a new [Sylvia]67-sylvia . [Madame Wachner]67-sylvia , looking at [his]152-chester grave , absorbed face , felt uneasy . The two following days dragged [themselves]4253-they uneventfully away . [Sylvia]67-sylvia did [her]67-sylvia best to be kind to [Bill Chester]79-chester , but [she]67-sylvia felt ill at ease , and could not help showing it . And then [she]67-sylvia missed the excitement and interest of [the Casino]2652-the casino . [Bill]79-chester had not suggested that [they]4253-they should go [there]210-there , and [she]67-sylvia would not be the one to do so . The long motoring expeditions [they]4253-they took each afternoon gave [her]67-sylvia no pleasure . [Her]67-sylvia heart was far away , in [Brittany]56-brittany ; in imagination [she]67-sylvia was standing by a grave surrounded by [a shadowy group of [men]286-men and [women]260-women]4256-a shadowy group of men and women , mourning [the old Marquise who had left [Count Paul]94-count paul the means to become once more [a self - respecting and respected member of the world to which [he]94-count paul belonged by right of birth]4260-a self - respecting and respected member of the world to which he belonged by right of birth .... Well , [she]67-sylvia would gamble too ! There came across [her]67-sylvia a curious feeling — one that gave [her]67-sylvia a certain painful joy — the feeling that [they]4298-they two were one . And then there came for [her]67-sylvia and for those who backed [her]67-sylvia , just as there had done on that first fateful evening at [the Casino]2652-the casino , an extraordinary run of good fortune . Again and again the cards were dealt to [Sylvia]67-sylvia , and again and again [she]67-sylvia turned up a Nine , [a Queen]4303-a queen , [a King]4304-a king , [an Eight—.]4305-an eight—. The more [she]67-sylvia won , the more [she]67-sylvia made [other people]2532-other people win , the more miserable [Sylvia]67-sylvia felt , and as [she]67-sylvia saw [Count Paul]94-count paul 's heap of notes and gold diminishing , [she]67-sylvia grew unutterably wretched . Eight hundred pounds ? What an enormous lot of money to risk in an evening ! Then there came a change . It seemed as if only good cards — variations on the fateful eights and nines — could be dealt [her]67-sylvia . Suddenly [she]67-sylvia pushed [her]67-sylvia chair back and got up .
